_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Introduction:
The City of Sunnyvale's Water Pollution Control Plant (SWPCP) uses chemicals such as chlorine and sulfur dioxide to disinfect treated wastewater to provide water safe for discharge to the environment and for recycled water for uses such as landscaping irrigation. Storing large quantities of these chemicals can be a hazard if they are not handled properly. We take our safety obligations for storing and using hazardous chemicals as seriously as we take providing reliable wastewater treatment.  This Summary describes the steps we take to prevent an accidental chemical release, to ensure we have a safely operated plant, and how we respond to an emergency.  To date, we have an excellent record in preventing accidental releases. Please feel free to contact Lorrie Gervin, Environmental Division Manager at (408) 730-7260 if you have questions.

Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies
The SWPCP implements programs to comply with other accidental release prevention regulations including California's OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program and the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP).  In the SWPCP Priorities Policy developed by management, Safety is listed at the number one priority and is not to be compromised for any other issue.  All employees are to ensure that both employees and the community are safe at all times from any harm related to operations at the SWPCP.  Compliance is the next priority in the SWPCP Priorities Policy and should be planned for as we plan for safety, so that there is never a need to make a choice between the two.  Compliance at the SWPCP means meeting the obligations to various federal, state, and local agencies, as well as protecting the environment and providing an important service to our customers and the citizens of Sunnyvale.

The SWPCP has written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) established for all plant processes related to PSM and RMP requirements.  Written operato

r training programs for plant processes are in use for new operators.  The SWPCP has a Safety Committee consisting of representatives from each section within the Plant that meets on a monthly basis to discuss safety issues and plant operations.  Each SWPCP section has bi-weekly staff safety training meetings to provide training on pertinent operations and plans, with many of the training sessions related to chlorine and sulfur dioxide process safety.

General Facility and Regulated Substances Information
The SWPCP is located at 1444 Borregas Avenue in Sunnyvale, near the southern tip of the San Francisco Bay. SWPCP treats wastewater from the City of Sunnyvale, a small section of the City of Cupertino, and a portion of the Moffett Field Naval Air Station, located in Sunnyvale.  The plant has a treatment capacity of 29.5 million gallons per day; average flow is currently 14-16 million gallons per day. Plant processes include preliminary treatment to remove large solids and grit, primary sedimentation to remove settlable solids, oxidation ponds as secondary treatment, biological treatment to convert ammonia to nitrates, flocculation and coagulation for algae removal, filtration to remove suspended solids, disinfection to inactivate disease-causing organisms, and dechlorination of treated water prior to discharge to render chlorine harmless in the final effluent.  The SWPCP is a 24-hour per day/7-day per week operation.  A Senior Operator is always on duty at the facility and will initiate established emergency response procedures in the event of an accidental release or other emergency situation.

The facility currently stores chlorine and sulfur dioxide, which are regulated substances under the RMP and CalARP rules. These are stored in one-ton cylinders and exceed the RMP and Cal ARP threshold quantities. The facility also produces methane gas in its digesters which is used to power influent pump engines and for the co-generation of electricity in two 800 kW generato

ed from the supplier before the truck is allowed onsite to unload.  Cylinders are received by SWPCP personnel from the supplier's truck.  Once inside the SWPCP, all chlorine and sulfur dioxide cylinders are immediately unloaded and placed inside storage buildings where they are safety-secured.  The containers are never left outside or unattended.  After the cylinders are secured in the storage buildings, an intruder alarm system is activated.  The intruder alarm system is active when SWPCP staff are not working in the storage buildings.

Process and Chemical Safety Information
Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazards, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of each regulated substance.  This information was compiled from numerous sources prior to conducting the Process Hazard Analysis.  It includes MSDS sheets, chlorine and sulfur dioxide background information, and chlorine and sulfur dioxide reaction chemistry.

Equipment safety information has been compiled on the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes, including maximum intended inventory, safe upper and lower temperatures, safe upper and lower pressures, and codes and standards used to design build, and operate the processes.  SWPCP also has procedures in place to update safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.   

Process Hazard Analysis
Plant staff, engineering, and administrative staff conducted an initial, detailed PHA in December 1993.  A revalidation of the PHA was conducted in December 1999 by a team of maintenance, operations, engineering, and administrative staff using the "Hazard and Operability" (HAZOP) method and "What If" methods as per acceptable approach guidance from EPA. Another revalidation using the HAZOP and "What if" methodologies was completed in January 2003 using a similar team make-up.   Both revalidations were led by a consultin

g industrial safety professional who was knowledgeable about the types of processes being used. 

A list of actions and suggested improvements from the hazard review findings of the December 1999 PHA revalidation was prepared and all actions (with one exception) were completed or addressed by January 2003.  The piping and chlorine evaporator/sulfonator corrosion inspection actions are scheduled for completion by March 31, 2005 and are discussed in the "Planned Changes to Improve Safety" section below.

Operating Procedures
The SWPCP maintains current, accurate, written operating procedures that include clear instruction for the operation of chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes.  Operating procedures are incorporated into operation and maintenance training programs.  Step-by-step written operating instructions were developed for the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems that include procedures for process start up, shutdown, and normal, alternate, and emergency operations.  The SWPCP Safety Committee reviews and updates procedures, as needed.  Also, procedures are developed and put in place whenever a change occurs that alters the steps needed to operate safely.  Operating procedures are developed and put in place prior to any new process equipment coming on-line or the start-up for a changed process.
Operations and Maintenance Training Program
Each SWPCP employee presently involved in operating or maintaining the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes is trained in an overview of the process and detailed, applicable operating and maintenance procedures.  The SWPCP training program provides information to help employees understand the nature and cause of problems arising from operations involving chlorine and sulfur dioxide, and increases awareness of employees with respect to process hazards.  The WCPCP training program includes both initial and refresher training that covers (1) a general overview of the process, (2) the properties and hazards of chlorine and sulfur

dioxide, (3) SCBA use and Level A protective gear qualifications (40-hour HAZWOPER class), (4) quarterly drills/training related to chlorine and sulfur dioxide safety procedures, and (5) a detailed review of process and operating procedures and safe work practices.

Training documentation maintained by SWPCP includes: (1) the dates of the most recent reviews or revision of the training program; (2) type of training provided; and (3) the type of competency testing or demonstrations used to ensure that staff understand the training.

Contractors
The SWPCP has procedures and policies in place to ensure that only contractors with good safety programs are selected to perform work on and around the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes.  Contractors are informed of process hazards, process area access limitation and emergency response procedures so that they may safely complete their work.  SWPCP sets minimum contractor safety performance requirements to perform work on or around the chlorine and sulfur dioxide process areas and equipment, holds contractor safety briefings before allowing contractors near or into the process areas, controls access to process areas, and evaluates contractor performance.

Mechanical Integrity Program
The SWPCP maintains the mechanical integrity of all facility equipment, including covered process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could potentially endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  We believe that this program is the primary line of defense against a release and addresses equipment testing and inspection, preventive maintenance schedules, and personnel training.  The SWPCP mechanical integrity program includes the following:
- Procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity through inspection and testing of process equipment based on instructions and recommendations from manufacturers, equipment vendors, industry codes, and prior operating experience.
- Implementation of the written procedures in performing i

nspections and tests on process equipment at specified intervals.
-Training of maintenance personnel in procedures for safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, line or equipment opening, avoidance and correction of unsafe conditions; and
-Procedures specifying training requirements for contract maintenance employees, as well as requiring contractors to use plant developed maintenance procedures for process areas.

Hot Work Permits
SWPCP requires employees and contractors to use safe work practices when performing "hot work" in, on, or around the chlorine and sulfur dioxide process areas, as well as other areas around the facility where flammable materials may be used or stored.  Employees must follow the requirements of the Welding, Brazing, Soldering, Cutting, and Related Hot Work SOP and a Hot Work Permit must be issued by a department supervisor before any hot work is performed outside of the designated welding booth.  Copies of all permits issued for the previous two years are kept on site.

Management of Change and Pre-startup Safety Reviews
The SWPCP has a process in place to implement changes or modifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions.  This systems allows employees to identify and review safety hazards, provide additional safety, process, or chemical information to existing data, evaluate the proposed change to confirm that it would not compromise system safety, and establish training requirements before implementation.  The SWPCP ensures that a pre-startup safety review is completed for any new process at the plant or for significant modifications to an existing covered process that requires a change in the process safety information.  All proposed process changes must be submitted in writing and include all schematics, diagrams, and specifications for review by Operations, Maintenance, and Management divisions and the plant-wide Safety Committee before plant management authorizes proposed changes.

Internal Complianc

e Audits
Safety audits of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide process equipment are conducted annually.  Internal compliance audits are completed every three years using a team of personnel who are knowledgeable about the RMP/PSM plan and the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes.  The team includes representatives from Operations, Maintenance, and Management, plus a consulting safety professional.  The team evaluates whether the RMP/PSM Plan and its implementation satisfy the requirements of the RMP/CalARP, and PSM, and if the plan is sufficient to ensure safe operation of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes.  The results of the audit are documented, recommendations reviewed and resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the RMP/PSM Plan are adopted.

Incident Investigation
In addition to its routine industrial accident investigation program, the SWPCP investigates all incidents involving chlorine or sulfur dioxide that caused or could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment, so that similar accidents can be prevented. The SWPCP trains employees to identify and report any incident that requires investigation.

An investigation team is assembled to investigate covered process incidents.  Results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate processes enhancements are implemented.  Incident investigation report findings are reviewed by affected staff, used to revise operating and maintenance procedures, and submitted to the Maintenance Manager and Supervisors for inclusion into existing training programs, if warranted, to prevent future incidents.  To date, only minor incidents or "near misses" have been investigated, as there have been no significant releases or injuries.

Toxic Gas Ordinance Compliance
The chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage systems include several safety features and are in full compliance with Santa Clara County's stringent Toxic Gas Ordinance, as well as the

Toxic Gas Ordinance (TGO) for the City of Sunnyvale (Sunnyvale Municipal Code Section 16.53).  Safety provisions include:
- Secondary containment containers and all process equipment are located within the building.  The building is under negative pressure under normal and emergency ventilation conditions.
- A 3,000 cubic feet per minute (cfm) packed-bed scrubber to treat exhausted air if a release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide occurs.
- Louvers automatically close upon detection of a leak and the room space is exhausted to the packed-bed scrubber.
- Sulfur dioxide and chlorine storage and use rooms are equipped with smoke detectors, gas leak detectors, and seismic detectors and manually activated panic buttons at the chlorine and sulfur dioxide facility exits. 
- Gas leak detectors in each chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage and use room are interconnected to the PLC system with a tiered action system that includes automatic shutdown of the building ventilation systems, activation of the scrubber system, activation of chlorine and sulfur dioxide shutoff valves, and activation of the audible and visual alarm system (plant siren) if triggered.  Automated dampers are used to direct airflow to the scrubber from the appropriate containment area. A sensor at the scrubber stack exit will provide automatic shutdown of the scrubber in the event of a detected release above the trigger level.
- Seismic detectors will cause liquid chlorine and sulfur dioxide supply valves to close and annunciate alarms to indicate the shutoff valves have closed in the event of significant seismic activity.
- Manually-activated panic buttons will cause the chlorine and sulfur dioxide supply valves to close and annunciate alarms to indicate the shutoff valves have closed.

Ancillary chlorine and sulfur dioxide process equipment used for handling chlorine and sulfur dioxide containers includes the following features:
- Containers are equipped with fusible plugs for pressure relief and steel prote

ctive housings for the valve area.
-  All valves and fittings used on the chlorine system are certified for chlorine use.
-  The header system is equipped with a frangible disk, shut-off valves, and a high-pressure switch.
-  The chlorine and sulfur dioxide evaporators are thermostatically controlled
-  The chlorine system pressure relief valve is vented through the scrubber
-  The facility maintains a Chlorine Institute Emergency "B" Kit for use in responding to a leak from the one-ton cylinders, self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBAs) and appropriate personal protection equipment for use in emergency response situations.  The SCBAs are also used by staff and are on "standby" during equipment change out.
- The SWPCP is enclosed by a fence and the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage areas are equipped with motion sensor alarms to notify operators of unauthorized entry to the buildings.
System alarms are monitored at the computer control center staffed with operators 24 hours per day, 7 days each week.

Facility maintenance:
- The SWPCP had a comprehensive written mechanical integrity program with an automated tracking and scheduling for the work order and preventive maintenance system. 
- The facility has a written Management of Change standard operating procedure that is to be used when changes to the process procedures, process chemicals, equipment, or technology may affect the chlorine or sulfur dioxide facilities.
- Items identified for improvement during HAZOP reviews as a part of the Process Hazard Analysis are tracked to ensure their implementation.

Staff training:
- SWPCP Operations and Maintenance staff receive chlorine and sulfur dioxide process and facility safety training five times each year.
- Additional safety training related to plant processes and operations is provided on a biweekly basis.  Annual updates regarding chlorine and sulfur dioxide safety plans are provided to all staff as a part of the regular safety program.

Five-Year Accident His

tory
There have been no releases of chlorine of sulfur dioxide in the last five years that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite and no known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.   

Emergency Response Program
The SWPCP has established a written emergency response program for employees to help safely respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances.  This program has been coordinated with the City of Sunnyvale - Certified Unified Public Agency (CUPA) emergency response agencies.  The program includes emergency response procedures and an evacuation plan specific to chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes.  Chlorine and sulfur dioxide area SWPCP operators are trained as first responders. Emergency response drills with other agencies are conducted annually.  Operator training and response for the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes are conducted quarterly.  Emergency operation and response procedures are reviewed at the time of the annual drill. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
A list of action items based on the chlorine and sulfur dioxide PHA completed on 01/23/03 was prepared and four action items were identified:
 -The raw material quality control item was completed on 5/30/03 when certificates of analysis for chlorine and sulfur dioxide quality were obtained from the distributors.
- Management reviewed the consequences of venting the Pressure Relief Valves (PRV) vent to the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage buildings rather than to the roof, as suggested in the PHA revalidation.  It was determined that any system failure, including a PRV release, would vent to the interior of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage rooms. If this happens, the TGO system sensors and operations procedures would initiate the air contaminant treatment process and chlorine/sulfur dioxide emergency response actions as per the facility's Standard Operating Procedures.  It was de

termined that venting the PRVs to the TGO ductwork was not necessary.
- The PHA results suggested that the frequency of chlorine and sulfur dioxide Evaporator/Sulfonator rotations should be reviewed and determine if any changes need to be made to meet manufacturers' recommendations.  Chlorine evaporators and sulfonators have a quarterly rotation.  This was found to meet the manufacturers' recommendations.
- Documentation of implementation of action items from previous PHA and audits was completed.  Seismic improvements to the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage areas and modified flexible connections at wall penetrations were completed.  In addition, rigid connections on the scrubber ventilation ducting were modified to allow flexibility and rigid pipe connections for piping inside the storage buildings were modified to allow limited displacement during seismic events.
- All Preventive Operational Procedures and Preventive Maintenance activities were reviewed by management to compare manufacturers' specifications for inspection and testing procedures for consistency.  It was found that the intervals for maintenance were established based on the manufacturers' recommendations and on the Chlorine Institute guidelines.  In some cases SWPCP has increased the inspection intervals and in some cases the inspection intervals were decreased, based on staff experience with a particular piece of equipment.
-   It was noted in the PHA evaluation that inspection and testing of the evaporators for corrosion had not been completed.  With the current piping configuration and system, it is not possible to complete an inspection for corrosion without taking apart all system elements.  A bid document was prepared in 2003 to obtain contractor services to replace piping and evaporator/sulfonator equipment.  However, no acceptable bids were received.  The current plan is to replace the piping to allow for chlorinator and sulfonator tank corrosion testing.  When the piping is replaced, it

will be designed to allow for corrosion testing of both the piping and the chlorinator/sulfonator tanks.  A new bid request is being prepared and it is anticipated that the necessary work will be completed by 03/31/05. 

A joint Sunnyvale Public Safety and SWPCP "first responder" training exercise to improve coordination in the event of an emergency release/intruder alert was done in May 2003. A new training exercise is currently in development with SWPCP staff and Sunnyvale Public Safety and is scheduled to occur in August 2004.

The Maintenance Manager will place documentation of the closeout of these actions in the RMP/Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide Safety facility file.
